text: Sorry to bother everyone, but what is metapopulation analysis? I recently stumbled across the term during some literature reviews. The paper I was reading mentioned this is a technique borrowed from biological modeling but didn't go into what this technique actually is before it was applied. Could someone either explain to me the gist of it or link me a resource where I could learn more about it? Thank you!

elements.text: Sorry to bother everyone, but what is metapopulation analysis? I recently stumbled across the term during some literature reviews. The paper I was reading mentioned this is a technique borrowed from biological modeling but didn't go into what this technique actually is before it was applied. Could someone either explain to me the gist of it or link me a resource where I could learn more about it? Thank you!

text: It's a term from ecology. If you have a large area with lots of smaller habitats, a species can go extinct in a habitat without it really being a problem, because members from another habitat will eventually immigrate from neighbouring habitats. So to get an overview of the status of that species, you need to consider the larger area as a "population of populations"

elements.text: It's a term from ecology. If you have a large area with lots of smaller habitats, a species can go extinct in a habitat without it really being a problem, because members from another habitat will eventually immigrate from neighbouring habitats. So to get an overview of the status of that species, you need to consider the larger area as a "population of populations"

text: Hunh... So I am curious <@U7HAYKY9X> - how would someone apply these to human populations where the question really isn't of extinction but more so of health and well-being. The papers I am looking at concern mobility patterns of individuals during an epidemic outbreak. Thoughts on how the transfer of techniques could be applied?

text:
I've never worked with this, this is all something I remember from my bachelor's student days. But I would imagine during this pandemic, you can model society as a large group of social bubbles where people see other people inside the bubble more.
So maybe one can consider the virus going extinct in social bubbles and migrating from bubble to bubble?
